newsitem.title: USA: IBM to unveil Internet software strategy.
newsitem.headline: IBM to unveil Internet software strategy.

text.p: International Business Machines Corp is expected to update its Internet software strategy on Tuesday, as it seeks to turn its $13 billion software business into more of a growth engine, analysts said.

IBM will unveil in San Francisco what it is calling a "Network Computing Framework," plus new software products, that will help make current IBM hardware and software more easily adaptable to the Internet and corporate networks.
IBM's top software executive, senior vice president John M. Thompson, will unveil its strategy with other officials, including Irving Wladawsky-Berger, head of the Internet unit.

"They are trying to build more and more offerings tying electronic commerce to large servers like mainframes and the databases that are supported behind those mainframes," said John Jones, a Salomon Brothers analyst.

IBM hopes to create a framework that will let software developers create Internet business applications or corporate network applications that make use of the vast repositories of data stored on IBM mainframes and other IBM computers. The strategy includes products from IBM, its Lotus Development Corp unit and Tivoli Systems. It will support Internet standards and languages, such as Sun Microsystems Inc's Java.

As part of the announcement, IBM is expected to unveil new Web server software for Lotus Notes, its groupware software. The software, which analysts said is called Lotus Go, is expected to be a lower-cost version of its Domino Web server software, aimed at small to medium-sized businesses.

IBM is also expected to tout applications it has designed to solve particular customer problems, such as a trading system it designed for discount brokerage Charles Schwab, for its online trading Web site that links to an IBM mainframe.
An IBM spokeswoman declined to comment on unannounced products, or to give further details on its strategy plans.
